revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Converse, Inc. | logo = Converse logo.svg | logo_size = 180px | type = [[Subsidiary]] | industry = [[Fashion accessory|Accessories]], [[apparel]], [[sporting goods]] Common slang term = converses | founded = {{start date and age|1908|2}}
[[Malden, Massachusetts]], U.S.{{cite Slang term web|url=http://chucksconnection.com/articles/ConverseArt73.html |title=Converse turns 100 |publisher=Chucksconnection.com |date=2008-05-29 |accessdate=2011-08-31}} | founder = Marquis Mills Converse | hq_location = [[Boston, Massachusetts]], U.S. | num_locations = More than 100
U.S. retail stores | num_locations_year = 2018 | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Davide Grasso
([[C.E.O]] and [[president (corporate title)|president]]) | products = [[Apparel]], [[clothing]], [[shoe]]s | revenue = {{increase}} [[United States dollar|$]]2.0 billion | revenue_year = 2015 | num_employees = 2,658 (in U.S) | parent = [[Nike, Inc.]] (2003-present) | website = {{URL|http://www.converse.com}} }} [[File:Converse red.JPG|thumb|A red pair of Converse Chuck Taylor All-Stars]] '''Converse''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|ɒ|n|v|ər|s}} is an American shoe company that primarily produces [[skating shoes]] and [[lifestyle brand]] [[footwear]] and [[apparel]]. Founded in 1908, it has been a [[subsidiary]] of [[Nike, Inc.]] since 2003.{{cite news |last=Wayne |first=Leslie |title=For $305 million, Nike buys Converse |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/07/10/business/10NIKE.html |newspaper=the New York Times |accessdate=March 27, 2016}} During World War II, the company shifted its manufacturing from the public, and instead made footwear for the military. It was one of the few producers of athletic shoes and for over a half century the company dominated the American court shoe market. From the 1970s, the company lost its dominant position after other companies presented their own styles. Converse shoes are distinguished by a number of features, including the company's star insignia, the All Star's rubber sole, smooth rounded toe, and wrap-around strip. Converse manufactures its products under the Cons, [[Chuck Taylor All-Stars|Chuck Taylor All-Star]], [[John Varvatos]], and [[Jack Purcell]] trade names. In addition to apparel and footwear, the company sells other items through retailers in over 160 countries and through approximately 75 company-owned [[retail stores]] across the [[United States]], and employed 2,658 in the U.S. in 2015.{{Cite web|title = Converse Inc Facts, information, pictures {{!}} Encyclopedia.com articles about Converse Inc|url = http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/Converse_Inc.aspx|website =www.encyclopedia.com|access-date = 2016-02-11}} ==Early years== [[File:Black Converse sneakers.JPG|thumb|Black Converse Sneakers]] At age 47, Marquis Mills Converse, who was previously a manager at a footwear manufacturing firm, opened the Converse Rubber Shoe Company in February 1908 in [[Malden, Massachusetts]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.tn/books?id=VaxzCgAAQBAJ&pg=RA2-PA231&dq=converse+history+timeline&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwij_aG-q6rYAhXLWRQKHZQyDVoQ6AEIKDAB#v=onepage&q=converse%20history%20timeline&f=false|title=The Impact of Globalization on the United States [3 volumes]|last=Bertho|first=Michelle|last2=Crawford|first2=Beverly|last3=Fogarty|first3=Edward A.|date=2008-09-30|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9780313083198|language=en}} The company was a rubber shoe manufacturer, providing winterized rubber soled footwear for men, women, and children. By 1910, Converse was producing shoes daily, but it was not until 1915 that the company began manufacturing athletic shoes. The company's catalyst came in 1917 when the [[Chuck Taylor All-Stars|Converse All-Star]] [[basketball]] shoe was introduced. Then in 1923, a basketball player named [[Chuck Taylor (salesman)|Charles H. "Chuck" Taylor]] walked into Converse complaining of sore feet. Converse gave him a job: he worked as a salesman and ambassador, promoting the shoes around the U.S., and in 1932 Taylor's signature was added to the All-Star patch on the classic, high-topped sneakers. He continued this work until shortly before his death in 1969.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Fv4rAAAAIBAJ&sjid=M20FAAAAIBAJ&pg=1717%2C8232748 |newspaper=Kentucky New Era |location=Hopkinsville |agency=Associated Press |title=Who the heck was Chuck Taylor anyway? |date=March 28, 2001 |page=A7 }} Converse also customized shoes for the [[New York Renaissance]] (the "Rens"), the first all–[[African American]] professional basketball team. In [[1961–62 NBA season|1962]], center [[Wilt Chamberlain]] of the [[1961–62 Philadelphia Warriors season|Philadelphia Warriors]] scored 100 points in an [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] game while wearing a pair of Chucks, taking a 169–147 victory over the [[1961–62 New York Knicks season|New York Knicks]] in [[Hershey, Pennsylvania]] on March 2.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0BMrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=SZwFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2432%2C576737 |newspaper=Reading Eagle |location=Pennsylvania |agency=Associated Press |title=Wilt Breaks NBA Record; Gets 100 Against Knicks |date=March 3, 1962 |page=7}} == 1941–2001: War, rise, bankruptcy, and new management == When the U.S. entered [[World War II]] in 1941, Converse shifted production to manufacturing rubberized footwear, outerwear, and protective suits for the military. The company resumed production of athletic footwear after the war's end. Popular during the 1950s and 1960s, Converse promoted an American image with its Converse Basketball Yearbook. Artist [[Charles Kerins]] created cover art that celebrated Converse's role in the lives of high school and college athletes. [[File:Jack Purcell shoes.jpg|thumb|right|Converse [[Jack Purcell]]s]] In the 1970s, Converse purchased the [[trademark|trademark rights]] to [[Jack Purcell]] sneakers from [[Goodrich Corporation|B.F. Goodrich]].{{cite web| last = Perrin|first = Charles |title = Old Sneakers (since 1935) - Goodrich (now Converse) Jack Purcell | url=http://sneakers.pair.com/m-jack.htm| accessdate =2011-08-31}} Converse lost their monopoly from the 1970s onward, with new competitors, including [[Puma AG|Puma]] and [[Adidas]], then [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], then a decade later [[Reebok]], who introduced new designs to the sports market. Converse found themselves no longer the official shoe of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA), a title they had relished for many years. The chevron and star insignia—a logo that remains on a large portion of Converse footwear other than the All Star—was created by Jim Labadini, an employee.{{cite web |url=http://www.complex.com/sneakers/2012/12/the-25-best-logos-in-sneaker-history/ |title=The 25 Best Logos in Sneaker History |publisher=Complex |date=December 6, 2012 |website=Complex |access-date=February 17, 2018 |quote=Jim Labadini helped cook up the Converse 2.0 logo during a time when sneaker brands where getting extremely competitive. The Converse Chevron logo marked the move forward into what would become an exciting time for the brand, thanks to some guys with nicknames like Dr. J, Magic and Legend.}} Canvas-rubber shoes regained popularity in the 1980s as casual footwear, but Converse eventually became over-dependent on the "All Stars" brand, whose market collapsed by 1989–1990. By the year 2000, Converse was slipping repeatedly into receivership as debt piled up yearly.{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/gen/news/2000/1017/823135.html |title=Converse Nears Corporate Extinction |last=Rovell |first=Darren |publisher=ESPN |date=October 18, 2000 |website=ESPN |access-date=February 17, 2018 |quote=Industry sources have confirmed that Converse has racked up $180 million in debt, and the announcement of the company's death is merely a formality.}} Converse filed for [[bankruptcy]] on January 22, 2001. Not too long after, on March 30, its last manufacturing plants in the U.S., closed down, as production fully moved overseas.?{{cite web |url=http://billingsgazette.com/business/converse-closes-chuck-taylor-plant/article_aa78045e-5e0e-5bd4-bf02-ef7033bc27c5.html |title=Converse closes Chuck Taylor plant |publisher=Associated Press |date=October 18, 2000 |website=Billings Gazette |access-date=March 30, 2001 |quote=The Lumberton plant that has churned out 8 million to 10 million pairs of Chuck Taylors a year has sent its 475 employees home, and the factory officially closes Saturday. Plants in Mission, Texas, and Reynosa, Mexico, are also being closed by the 93-year-old company.}} In April 2001, Footwear Acquisitions, led by Marsden Cason and Bill Simon, purchased the brand from bankruptcy and added industry partners Jack Boys, Jim Stroesser, Lisa Kempa, and David Maddocks to lead the turnaround of America's Original Sports Company.{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/jul/16/business/fi-22900 |title=Getting Sneaker Maker Converse Back on Its Feet |publisher=Associated Press |last=Pope |first=Justin |date=July 16, 2001 |website=Los Angeles Times |access-date=February 17, 2018 |quote=Investors Marsden Cason and William Simon, through their company Footwear Acquisition, saw an opportunity in the Converse name.}} ==Nike== In July 2003, [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] paid [[United States dollar|$]]309 million to acquire Converse. Nike approached the 1980s revival around 2010 to relaunch the footwear. Nike also expanded the Converse brand to other businesses apart from shoes, much akin to its other brands. By November 2012, Converse had disappeared completely from the NBA, as the last dozen players wearing the brand either left the NBA or switched shoes over a period of a year and a half. [[Carlos Arroyo]] went overseas in late 2011, and [[Maurice Evans (basketball)|Maurice Evans]] last played for the [[2011–12 Washington Wizards season|Washington Wizards]] in April [[2011–12 NBA season|2012]]. Nine switched to Nike: [[Acie Law]] (who went overseas) in late 2011; [[JJ Barea]] and [[Kirk Hinrich]] during the [[2011–12 NBA season|2011–12]] season; [[Luke Harangody]] and [[Larry Sanders (basketball)|Larry Sanders]] after the season; [[Elton Brand]], [[Lou Williams|Louis Williams]], and [[Kyle Korver]] for the [[2012–13 NBA season|2012–13]] season; and [[Chris Andersen]] during the season. [[Udonis Haslem]], the last NBA player wearing Converse on the court, followed [[2012–13 Miami Heat season|Miami Heat]] teammate [[Dwyane Wade]] to switch to [[Li Ning Company Limited|Li-Ning]] in late November 2012. Celebrities who have worn Converse include [[Snoop Dogg]], [[Kristen Stewart]] and [[Rihanna]]. The growth of Converse as a casual fashion accessory contributed to $1.7 billion in revenue in 2014 and $2 billion in 2015.{{Cite web|title = NIKE, INC. Reports Fiscal 2015 Fourth Quarter And Full Year Results|url = http://news.nike.com/news/nike-inc-reports-fiscal-2015-fourth-quarter-and-full-year-results|website = NIKE, Inc.|access-date = 2016-02-11}} === New headquarters === [[File:Converse Headquarters building.jpg|thumb|210px|Converse world headquarters building on [[Boston]]'s Lovejoy Wharf]] In January 2013, Converse announced plans for a new headquarters building, and moved in April 2015. It was constructed near [[North Station]] in downtown Boston, on the [[Lovejoy Wharf]], overlooking the Charles River as part of a major site overhaul and restoration of public waterfront access.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20130108006830/en/Converse-Announces-Global-Headquarters-City-Boston|title=Converse Announces New Global Headquarters in the City of Boston|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2018}} The 10-story {{convert|214,000|sqft|adj=on}} office building includes a permanent music recording studio for the new "Converse Rubber Tracks" project, {{convert|5000|sqft|adj=on}} gym with a separate yoga studio designed in partnership with Nike, and a new {{convert|3500|sqft|adj=on}} retail Flagship Store.{{Cite web|title = CONVERSE OFFICIALLY OPENS WORLD HEADQUARTERS IN BOSTON AND DEBUTS NEW FLAGSHIP STORE|url = http://media.converse.com/news/converse-officially-opens-world-headquartesr-in-boston-and-debuts-new-flagship-store#/inline/33242|website = Converse Media|access-date = 2016-02-15}} === Chuck Taylor All Star II === An improved model of the [[Chuck Taylor All-Star]], the ''Chuck Taylor II'', was announced by company management in July, 2015.Converse's new Chuck Taylors get a comfort boost, ''Boston Globe'', July 22, 2015; [https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2015/07/21/after-years-converse-set-unveil-chuck-taylor/RdAdxoiLOs8dva8tHtVxLN/story.html?p1=Article_Trending_Most_Viewed Minimalist sneaker launched in 1917 receives upgrade with Nike tech] The Chuck Taylor II's were released on July 28, 2015.{{Cite web|title = CONVERSE USHERS IN NEW ERA WITH GROUND-BREAKING CHUCK TAYLOR ALL STAR II|url = http://media.converse.com/news/converse-ushers-in-new-era-with-ground-breaking-chuck-taylor-all-star-ii|website = Converse Media|access-date = 2016-02-11}} Incorporating Nike technology, it retains the most of outward appearance of the original while employing a modern lightweight lunarlon insole. The notable changes made to the new sneakers are the removal of the wrap around strip, premium canvas with higher quality stitching, and a no slip tongue. ===Skateboarding market=== Under the "CONS" name, Converse launched its skateboarding program in 2009 with a team of "ambassadors": Kenny Anderson, Anthony Pappalardo, Nick Trapasso, Sammy Baca, Ethan Fowler, Raymond Molinar, and [[Rune Glifberg]].{{cite web|title=Cons Comes Back: A Look at Converse Skateboarding|url=http://push.ca/blogs/andrewsk/archive/2009/05/13/cons-comes-back-a-look-at-converse-skateboarding.aspx|work=Push.ca|publisher=Bell Canada|accessdate=9 September 2012|author=asayer|date=13 May 2009}} In 2012, the company added [[Jason Jessee]] and Mike Anderson to its ambassadors team.{{cite web|title=Ambassadors|url=http://www.converse.com/content/landing/index.aspx?command=N:3066-100060|work=Converse.com|publisher=Converse Inc|accessdate=9 September 2012|year=2012}} In August 2012, Converse sponsored a skate event at [[Huntington Beach]], [[California]], US. Trapasso, Tom Remillard,{{cite web|title=Nick Trapasso, Tom Remillard & Robbie Russo at Coastal Carnage! Weeke ... |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c0-ChrtyTyQ|work=YouTube|publisher=Google, Inc|accessdate=20 January 2013|author=RIDE Channel |author2=Rob Brink |author3=Erica Yary|format=Video upload|date=3 August 2012}} [[Aaron Homoki]], Greyson Fletcher, Ben Raemers, Ben Hatchell, Robbie Russo, and Ben Raybourn participated in the competition that was held. Raybourn eventually won the US$20,000 grand prize and Homoki won the US$3,000 Best Trick contest.{{cite web|title=RAYBOURN CRUISES THROUGH CARNAGE|url=http://xgames.espn.go.com/skateboarding/article/8238185/ben-raybourn-wins-converse-coastal-carnage|work=ESPN Action Sports|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures|accessdate=20 January 2013|author=Lance Dawes|author2=Cory Williams|date=6 August 2012}} As of July 2014, the CONS skateboard team consisted of original members Anderson, Trapasso, Baca, and Glifberg, while Jessee, Anderson, Julian Davidson, Remillard, Zered Basset, Ben Raemers, Jake Johnson, Eli Reed, Louis Lopez, Sage Elsesser, and Sean Pablo were subsequently added. Bassett filmed a new advertisement that was broadcast online during July 2014, in which he skateboarded through [[New York City]] in a newly launched skate shoe version of the Converse Weapon model, the "CONS Weapon Skate."{{cite web|author1=Brian Farmer|title=Converse Launches the CONS Weapon Skate Shoe with Short Film featuring Zered Bassett|url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/2014/07/20/converse-cons-weapon-skate/|website=High Snobiety|publisher=Titel Media|accessdate=26 July 2014|date=20 July 2014}} === Lawsuit === Starting in July 2008, Converse sent around 180 cease-and-desist letters to over 30 other companies who they claimed were violating the alleged Chuck Taylor All Star trademark and selling so-called look-alike sneakers. In October 2014, Converse filed a lawsuit against 30 companies for allegedly infringing on its generic sneaker style's bumper toe, striped midsole and toe cap. The brand argued that companies were violating an alleged common-law trademark by importing sneakers with similar elements. A number of companies settled with Converse and they were dropped from the list.Schiavenza, Matt, "Why Converse is Fighting to Keep All Stars Cool," The Atlantic, 15 October 2014.Butler-Young, Sheena, "Iconix and Fila Settle in Converse Lawsuit Saga," Footwear News, 9 April 2015. In November 2015, Charles Bullock, chief administrative judge at the International Trade Commission, preliminarily ruled that several brands Converse filed against were violating Converse's outsole design trademarks, i.e. the pattern on the bottom of the sole of the shoe. Judge Bullock further ruled that while [[Skechers]] "Twinkle Toes" brands did share similarities to Converse, "Twinkle Toes" were different enough and marketed in a way for it not to be mistaken for [[Chuck Taylor All-Stars]].{{Cite web|title = Converse Trademark Lawsuit: Skechers Declares Victory, Mixed Ruling Expected Overall|url = http://footwearnews.com/2015/business/uncategorized/converse-trademark-lawsuit-ruling-skechers-twinkle-toes-bobs-171481/|website = Footwear News|access-date = 2016-02-11|language = en-US|first = Margaret|last = Sutherlin}} Judge Bullock also ruled that most of the shoes sold by Highline United under the Ash brand did not infringe and that Converse did not have a valid common law mark for its midsole. On June 23, 2016, the anniversary of the death of Chuck Taylor, the International Trade Commission ruled that Converse's alleged trade dress for the midsole design of a combined toe cap, toe bumper, and stripe was not entitled to trademark protection under the common law and found invalid Converse's federal trademark registration. This case is currently on appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. An oral hearing in that appeal was conducted on February 8, 2018. The decision in that appeal is pending. == Shoes == === The Weapon === [[File:Converse Weapons.JPG|thumb|right|The Weapon, manufactured in many different color schemes]] In 1986, Converse released "The Weapon" basketball shoe. Manufactured in two color schemes to match the kit colors of basketball teams, it has been available in both high-top and low cut varieties. The unique{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}} aspect of this shoe is the leather construction throughout, including the inside heel which is also heavily padded for comfort. Converse re-released "The Weapon" classic (which [[Kobe Bryant]] wore at least three times in 2002 and [[Andre Miller]] wore in 2002 from mid August to early September) several times from 1999 to 2003 and after, "The Loaded Weapon" in 2003, "The Weapon 86" in 2008 (and the Poorman version in 2009, and the [[John Varvatos]] version in 2012), "The Weapon EVO" in 2009, and its successor "The Star Player EVO" (sometimes reduced to "The Star Plyr EVO" or "The Star Ply EVO") in 2010. The first endorsers of "The Weapon" were [[Larry Bird]] and [[Magic Johnson]], who were prominently featured in a Converse commercial set in Bird's hometown of [[French Lick, Indiana]] in 1985. They were also worn by [[Axl Rose]] in the [[Guns N' Roses]] music video "[[Estranged (single)|Estranged]]". === Special editions === [[File:converseFashion.jpg|thumb|Converse fashion in [[Paris]]]] [[File:Largest collection of Converse All-Stars.JPG|thumb|right|Joshua Mueller, [[Guinness Book of World Records]] holder for largest collection of "Chucks"]] Several special editions of Converse shoes have been made, including [[DC Comics]], [[Pink Floyd]], [[The Ramones]], [[AC/DC]], [[Sailor Jerry]], [[Metallica]], [[The Clash]], [[Dr. Seuss]], [[Grateful Dead]], [[Ozzy Osbourne]], [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[Miley Cyrus]] (who helped advertise rainbow designed converse for Pride Month in 2017 {{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/lifestyle/7825845/miley-cyrus-teams-up-with-converse-for-pride-month|title=Miley Cyrus Teams Up With Converse To Create a Collection of Pride-Inspired Sneakers|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-06-12}} and designed the 2018 collection also for pride month in conjunction with her charity [[Happy Hippie Foundation]] {{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/miley-cyrus-pride-2018-converse-collaboration-interview|title=Miley Cyrus Talks Equal Rights, Gender Fluidity, and Her Pride Collaboration With Converse|last=|first=|date=|work=Vogue|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en}}), [[Drew Brophy]], [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]], [[Bad Meets Evil]], [[Green Day]], [[Gorillaz]], [[Matt and Kim]], [[Black Sabbath]], the Control, green, brown or camouflage edition, [[Super Mario]] and Danny Potthoff. Three new designs were created for high tops, inspired by [[The Who]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} Additionally, Converse have to date made an appearance in over 650 films, appearing in movies such as ''[[Back to the Future]]'', ''[[I, Robot (film)|I, Robot]]'', ''[[Grease (film)|Grease]]'' and ''[[Stand by Me (film)|Stand by Me]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.chucksconnection.com/films.html|title=All Star Films|website=www.chucksconnection.com|access-date=2018-06-14}} [[David Tennant]] (playing the [[Tenth Doctor]]) wore a variety of Hi-top Converse on science-fiction show ''[[Doctor Who]]'', including red and cream versions.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbcamerica.com/anglophenia/2011/07/how-to-dress-like-the-tenth-doctor|title=How To Dress Like The Tenth Doctor {{!}} BBC America|work=BBC America|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}} July 2018, Converse teamed up the BT21, a millennial pop character created by South Korean hip-hop group [[BTS (band)|BTS]] to launch the special collaboration line of Chuck Taylor All-Stars featured the illustrations of BT21 characters, it's currently available limited quantities in Asia starting from July 27.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2018/07/23/bts-team-converse-bt21-sneakers|title=BTS team up with Converse for BT21 sneakers|website=SBS PopAsia|language=en|access-date=2018-10-19}} In 2018, [[Tyler, the Creator]] teased a [[Golf Wang|GOLF le Fleur]] x Converse One Star sneaker, which was made up of [[jute]].{{Cite news|url=https://hypebae.com/2018/10/tyler-the-creator-golf-le-fleur-converse-chuck-taylor-burlap-release|title=Here's when the GOLF le FLEUR* x Converse Chuck Taylor "Burlap" Pack will release|work=HYPEBAE|access-date=2018-10-25}} The collection is set to be launched in November 2018 and will be available in two different colors.{{Cite news|url=https://hypebeast.com/2018/10/tyler-the-creator-golf-le-fleur-converse-chuck-taylor-70-one-star-burlap-canvas-release-details|title=GOLF le FLEUR* x Converse Chuck Taylor "Burlap" Pack Gets Official Look & Release Date|work=HYPEBEAST|access-date=2018-10-25}} ==Causes== A special collection called "1Hund (RED)", whereby fifteen percent of the profits are used to support [[HIV/AIDS]] prevention, was released by the brand. One hundred artists from around the world were chosen to create designs for the collection as part of the (RED) campaign. Professional skateboarder, Anthony Pappalardo, who, at the time, was also associated with another (RED) participant, Girl skateboards—Pappalardo was sponsored by Chocolate skateboards, a brand distributed by the [[Girl Distribution Company|Crailtap]], the distribution company that owns both Girl and Chocolate—released a (RED) edition of his high-selling{{cite web|title = Anthony Pappalardo|url = http://site.48blocks.com/anthony-pappalardo|work = 48 Blocks|publisher = 48 Blocks|accessdate = 20 January 2013|year = 2012}} signature skate shoe model.{{cite web|title = ANTHONY PAPPALARDO'S PROJECT RED CONS PRO MODEL|url = http://skateboarding.transworld.net/1000096243/gear/shoes/anthony-pappalardos-project-red-cons-pro-model/|work = Transworld Skateboarding|publisher = Bonnier Corporation|accessdate = 20 January 2013|author = Blair Alley|date = 2 December 2009}} A short video piece was published on the internet{{cite web|title=Anthony Pappalardo and (RED)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wvkTUwB26Zo |publisher=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=20 January 2013|author=Aaron Meza|author2=crailtap|format=Video upload|date=30 November 2009}} and Pappalardo explains in it:
I got into woodworking about two years ago, through a buddy of mine who I used to skate with every day—he turned into a woodworker. So he gave me this scrap box of wood, and, basically, I just wanted to do something with it ... make something with it. It just definitely started consuming me like skating did. I wanted to read about it, you know? Go on the internet and watch videos about it, and just learn anything and everything I could about woodworking. The first thing I ever made was a bench, and that's, kinda, what I've been making ever since. the cool thing about working with Product (RED) is just by doing the two things that I love, I'm also able to help people.
Pappalardo's first signature shoe with Converse was released in February 2010 and it was produced in the (RED) colorway. In 2012, Converse is listed as a partner in the (RED) campaign, together with other brands such as [[Nike Inc.]], Girl, and Bugaboo. The campaign's mission is to prevent the transmission of the HIV virus from mother to child by 2015 (the campaign's byline is "Fighting For An AIDS Free Generation").{{cite web |title=(RED) |url=http://www.joinred.com/aboutred/red-partners/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120528191704/http://www.joinred.com/aboutred/red-partners/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=28 May 2012 |work=(RED) Partners |publisher=(RED), a division of The ONE Campaign |accessdate=13 October 2012 |year=2012 |df= }} In winter of 2018, Converse teamed up with a number of influential figures and taste-makers from the Los Angeles area to create an exclusive collection paying to those who help move the culture forward in the city. Among those selected by the Boston-based footwear brand for this L.A.-themed collection is [[Vince Staples]], Dr. Woo, Rocket, BornXRaised, and Clot ==Former Converse college teams== * [[Marquette Golden Eagles men's basketball|Marquette Golden Eagles]]—switched to Jordan when most famous alum, [[Dwyane Wade]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/42433795|title=Dwyane Wade Gets His First Jordan Signature Shoe|last=Rovell|first=Darren|date=2011-04-05|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-10-19}} signed with Jordan * [[Western Kentucky Hilltoppers basketball|Western Kentucky Hilltoppers]]—shoes only Due to Converse withdrawing from performance basketball shoes,{{cite web|url=http://www.wwd.com/footwear-news/business/on-star-qa-with-converses-jim-calhoun-7105883?full=true|title=Footwear News|website=Footwear News|accessdate=10 May 2018}} there are no professional players or college teams wearing Converse shoes, except on occasion Asi Taulava.{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/389226/sports/basketball/pba-after-wearing-chuck-taylors-asi-taulava-wants-to-bring-back-short-shorts|title=PBA: After wearing Chuck Taylors, Asi Taulava wants to bring back short shorts|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2018}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{Commons|Converse}} * [http://www.converse.com/ Official web site] * [https://jobs.converse.com Careers at Converse] {{Nike}} [[Category:1908 establishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:1970s fashion]] [[Category:1980s fashion]] [[Category:1990s fashion]] [[Category:2000s fashion]] [[Category:2010s fashion]] [[Category:Athletic shoe brands]] [[Category:Clothing brands of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Boston]] [[Category:Companies based in Middlesex County, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1908]] [[Category:Nike brands]] [[Category:Shoe companies of the United States]] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of the United States]] [[Category:Sportswear brands]]

{{Distinguish|Cooldown}} [[File:John O'Brien has a drink (2006).jpg|thumb|Rehydrating after exercise |318x318px]]'''Cooling down''' (also known as limbering down) is an easy exercise, done after a more intense activity, to allow the body to gradually transition to a resting or near-resting state. Depending on the intensity of the exercise, cooling down can involve a slow jog or walk. With lower intensities stretching can be used. Cooling down allows the heart rate to return to its resting rate. Anecdotally cooling down may reduce dizziness for professional or serious athletes and vocal performers after strenuous workouts.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.2478/v10078-012-0079-4 | volume=35 | title=The Effect of Warm-Up and Cool-Down Exercise on Delayed Onset Muscle Soreness in the Quadriceps Muscle: a Randomized Controlled Trial | journal=Journal of Human Kinetics}}</ref> Studies are currently inconclusive as to whether the process actually reduces [[Delayed onset muscle soreness|delayed-onset muscle soreness]]<ref>Law RYW and Herbert RD(2007) Warm-up reduces delayed-onset muscle soreness but cool-down does not: a randomised controlled trial. ''The Australian Journal of Physiotherapy'' 53: 91–95.</ref> and muscle soreness not caused by [[lactic acid|lactate]] production during intense exercise.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bale | first1 = P | last2 = James | first2 = H | year = 1991 | title = Massage, warmdown and rest as recuperative measures after short term intense exercise | url = | journal = Physiotherapy in Sport | volume = 13 | issue = | pages = 4–7 }}</ref> Some have shown a weak correlation: however, the majority of recent studies discount the relationship.<ref>[http://www.degruyter.com/view/j/hukin.2012.35.issue-1/v10078-012-0079-4/v10078-012-0079-4.xml] DeFatta, Rima A., and Robert T. Sataloff. "The Value Of Vocal Warm-Up And Cool-Down.,vfs;';g' Exercises: Questions And Controversies." Journal of Singing 69.2 (2012): 173-175. Education Source. Web. 10 Apr. 2014.</ref> One study has shown that athletes who perform an appropriate cool-down are less likely to become injured.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Malliou | first1 = Paraskevi | display-authors = 1 | last2 = et al | year = 2007 | title = Reducing Risk Of Injury Due To Warm Up And Cool Down In Dance Aerobic Instructors | url = | journal = Journal of Back & Musculoskeletal Rehabilitation | volume = 20 | issue = 1| pages = 29–35 | doi=10.3233/bmr-2007-20105}}</ref>
==Procedure== Cool downs should involve the following important steps to ensure an effective cool down. After exercise, a gradual yet continuous decrease in exercise intensity (i.e. from a hard run to an easy jog to a brisk walk) should be the first step in cooling down the body. Duration can vary for different people, but 3–10 minutes is considered adequate. Stretching, especially static stretching allows the muscles to be elongated and lengthened.<ref name=":1" /> This is the next step athletes should take to cool down. Rehydration is an essential part of the procedure and should be done either during stretching and light intensity or after these steps. Refuelling the body with water and sports drinks will keep the body hydrated.<ref>{{Cite journal|author1=Coso, J.D. |author2=Estevez, E. |author3=Baquero, R. |author4= Mora-Rodriguez, R. |last-author-amp=yes |date=2008|title=Anaerobic performance when rehydrating with water or commercially available sports drink during prolonged exercise in heat.|url=http://bv8ja7kw5x.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info:sid/summon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=Anaerobic+performance+when+rehydrating+with+water+or+commercially+available+sports+drinks+during+prolonged+exercise+in+the+heat&rft.jtitle=Applied+Physiology%2C+Nutrition%2C+and+Metabolism&rft.au=Juan+Del+Coso&rft.au=Emma+Estevez&rft.au=Raúl+Antonio+Baquero&rft.au=Ricardo+Mora-Rodriguez&rft.date=2008-04-01&rft.pub=Canadian+Science+Publishing+NRC+Research+Press&rft.issn=1715-5312&rft.volume=33&rft.issue=2&rft.spage=290&rft.externalDocID=1459079771&paramdict=en-AU|journal=Applied Physiology, Nutrition & Metabolism|doi=10.1139/H07-188|pmid=18347684|access-date=May 2016 |volume=33 |pages=290–8}}</ref>[[File:Stretching-muscles-579122 640.jpg|thumb|310x310px|Static stretching]]
== Stretching == [[Stretching]] is a very important factor in the procedure of cooling down. Stretching allows the bodies muscles to build elasticity and repair from aerobic and anaerobic exercise.
Static stretching is the appropriate form of stretching to aid in the cooling down procedure. It aids in decreasing the body’s temperature, removing lactic acid from the muscles and increasing flexibility.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://stretchcoach.com/articles/cool-down/|title=Cool Down Exercises - 3 parts to an effective cool down|website=stretchcoach.com|access-date=2016-05-17}}</ref> Each stretch should be held for a minimum of 10–20 seconds and stretched to the point of mild discomfort but not pain.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ausport.gov.au/participating/resources/coaches/tools/the_training_session/Warmup-Cooldown|title=The warm up and cool down|last=Australian Institute of Sport|first=|website=www.ausport.gov.au|publisher=Australian Sports Commission|language=English|access-date=2016-05-17}}</ref> Each muscle used in mid-high intensity exercise should then be stretched during the cool down.<ref name=":0" />
== Half-time cooling down == This is a popular process for elite sporting clubs and athletes. It involves using either ice vests, cooling products or manually cooling down the body through gentle light intensity exercise to cool down the body during half-time or breaks in an activity or sport. Half- time cooling down has proven to decrease body temperature and increase aerobic performance.<ref>{{Cite journal|author1=Hornery D.J |author2=Papalia S |author3=Mujika I |author4=Hahn A |date=March 2005|title=Physiological and performance benefits of halftime cooling|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com.ipacez.nd.edu.au/science/article/pii/S1440244005800209|journal=Journal of Science and Medicine in Sport|doi=10.1016/S1440-2440(05)80020-9|pmid=|access-date=May 2016 |volume=8 |pages=15–25}}</ref> Many sporting groups use cooling down jackets during half-time. Australian elite sporting teams such as those in the AFL, Olympic teams, military and elite athletes across all sporting fields use cooling down vests to increase performance and gain a competitive advantage over their competition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.arcticheat.com.au/sporting/|title=Sporting|last=Arctic Heat|date=|website=Arctic Heat - High Tech Cooling Vests|publisher=Arctic Heat|access-date=May 2016}}</ref>
==Cardiovascular Issues, Health, and Heart rate== [[File:Xx0896 - Cycling Atlanta Paralympics - 3b - Scan (173).jpg|thumb|Paralympian using an ice vest]] During aerobic exercise, peripheral veins, particularly those within a muscle, dilate to accommodate the increased blood flow through exercising muscle. The [[skeletal-muscle pump]] assists in returning blood to the heart and maintaining cardiac output. A sudden cessation of strenuous exercise may cause blood to pool in peripheral dilated veins which may cause [[varicose veins]]. A cool-down period allows a more gradual return to [[Vein#Venous tone|venous tone]]. The heart will also need to beat faster to adequately oxygenate the body and maintain [[blood pressure]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://doc.med.yale.edu/heartbk/12.pdf|title=High Blood pressure|last=Moser|first=Marvin|date=May 2016|website=Yale University School of Medicine: Heart book|publisher=Yale University|access-date=}}</ref>
It is theorised that individuals predisposed to, suffering from, or at risk for cardiovascular disease may be at risk for potential negative cardiovascular outcomes if a cool down is not completed following exercise bouts due to a rapid decrease in blood reaching areas of the heart (with narrowed blood vessels due to present cardiovascular disease).<ref> {{cite news | last = Kolata | first = Gina | title = Is the Exercise Cool-Down Really Necessary? | newspaper = The New York Times | location = New York | date = 13 October 2009 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/15/health/nutrition/15best.html }} </ref> This, however, is only a theory, and clinical evidence for this is currently lacking.
Muscular and skeletal injuries have also been found to increase when the cool down procedure is neglected. Ankle injuries are one of the most common injuries athletes and participants are at risk of obtaining when the cool down is performed ineffectively or not at all.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Goossens, L. Verrelst, R. Cardon, G. De Clercq, D.|date=2012|title=Sports injuries in physical education teacher education students|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com.ipacez.nd.edu.au/doi/10.1111/sms.12054/epdf|journal=Scandinavian Journal of Medicine & Science in Sports|doi=10.1111/sms.12054|pmid=|access-date=May 2016|volume=24|pages=683–691}}</ref> Injuries are decreased significantly when the cool down is performed for an adequate amount of time compared to only a short period of time.<ref name=":2" />

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Use British English|date=September 2017}} {{more footnotes|date=December 2010}}
[[File:Lotus 18 Stirling Moss Monaco 1961.jpg|thumb|[[Stirling Moss]]'s [[1961 Monaco Grand Prix]]-winning [[Lotus 18]], one of the Donington Grand Prix Collection's most famous exhibits.]] [[File:Stewart SF 1 01.jpg|thumb|A [[Jan Magnussen]] Stewart SF1, example of the range and depth of machinery in the collection.]]
The '''Donington Grand Prix Collection''', sometime known as the ''Donington Grand Prix Exhibition'', was a museum of [[motor racing]] cars, based at the [[Donington Park]] motor racing circuit in [[Leicestershire]], England. The museum closed permanently on 5 November 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.autosport.com/historics/news/139307/donington-collection-museum-to-close|title=Donington Collection museum to close next month|first=Paul|last=Lawrence|website=autosport.com|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref>
== Overview == With five halls and over 130 exhibits, the Donington Grand Prix Collection comprises the largest exhibition of [[Grand Prix motor racing|Grand Prix]] cars in the world.{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} The collection contains vehicles from many forms of open-wheel, single-seater racing, but is primarily focussed on Grand Prix and [[Formula One]] machinery. The museum was formed by the late [[Tom Wheatcroft]] in March 1973 and is based on Wheatcroft's personal collection of vehicles. These include some that Wheatcroft's own motor racing team ran for drivers such as [[Roger Williamson]] and [[Derek Bell (auto racer)|Derek Bell]], although many cars exhibited are on loan from other owners. Various external collections of [[automobilia]] and motor racing [[ephemera]] have been donated to the museum over the years.
Specific attractions include the world's only complete collection of [[Vanwall]] cars, a near-complete collection of [[McLaren (racing)|McLaren]] Formula One cars from the team's inception to the early 2000s, and extensive collections of [[WilliamsF1|Williams]] and [[British Racing Motors|BRM]] cars (including examples of both notorious BRM [[V16 engine|V16]]-powered machines as well as the [[H16 engine|H16]]-powered BRM P83). The collection also has examples of four different [[four-wheel drive]] Formula One cars, including an unraced [[Cosworth]] car. Another star exhibit is the [[Lotus 18]] with which [[Stirling Moss]] won the [[1961 Monaco Grand Prix]], along with [[Jim Clark]]'s World Championship-winning [[Lotus 25]]. Noticeable, however, is the distinct lack of Ferrari vehicles, 3 in all, but fine examples nonetheless. First being a [[Ferrari 312]] driven by Chris Amon, second a [[312B]] and thirdly, a [[Ferrari F2000]] (The particular chassis driven to victory in the [[2000 Canadian Grand Prix]], one of nine victories for [[Michael Schumacher]] in his maiden championship winning series with Ferrari), conversely, the establishment houses the [[Jordan 191]] in which he made his formula 1 debut in 1991. The 1998 [[Jordan 198]], the most successful in Jordan's history, (the chassis being the one Damon Hill drove to victory in a 1-2 with team mate [[Ralf Schumacher]] at the [[1998 Belgian Grand Prix]] at [[Spa Francorchamps]]) also figures. Another interesting exhibit is an Auto Union, built from pre-war plans following the factory's destruction by [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] bombing during [[World War II]]. Wheatcroft has also supplemented the racing car collection with some additional notable cars, including a replica of the personal [[Bugatti Royale]] of [[Ettore Bugatti]].
Augmenting the car collections are the world's largest collection of motor racing helmets; [[Fangio]], [[Graham Hill]],<!-- Hill's name in full to clarify that it's Graham, not Damon --> [[Nigel Mansell|Mansell]], [[James Hunt|Hunt]] and [[Fernando Alonso|Alonso]] amongst others, a small collection of racing [[motorcycles]], including a [[Daijiro Kato]] Honda and a [[Barry Sheene]] Heron Texaco [[Suzuki]] and a number of collections of trophies and awards gained by a selection of British drivers and riders. In addition to exhibits, the Donington Grand Prix Collection museum also incorporates a conference suite and gift shop.
The Donington Grand Prix Collection was closed briefly in late 2009 in the wake of the death of Tom Wheatcroft and Donington Ventures Leisure Ltd. entering administration. It reopened in January 2010, along with the cafe and race control offices.<ref>Matt Beer, [http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/80753 Wheatcrofts vow to reopen Donington], ''[[Autosport]]'', 10 January 2010.</ref>
The museum sold the Jim Clark Lotus 25 c.2008 to an unknown private collector. Although it is no longer on public display, it has given the car the chance to be raced on track by Damon Hill and David Coulthard. Several other Formula 1 cars have also disappeared from the museum including Jackie Stewart's 1973 championship winning Tyrrell, Lotus 72 and Ferrari F2000. These cars may have been sold in order to solve Donington's financial problems when it enlarged the circuit and attempted to host the 2012 British Grand Prix.
==The McLaren Hall== [[File:Mclaren MP4 8.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Ayrton Senna]]'s [[McLaren MP4/8|MP4/8]] from Donington GP '93 .]] [[File:Donington McLaren Hall 3.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Part of McLaren Hall at Donington Grand Prix Collection]] [[File:Donington McLaren Hall 2.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Part of McLaren Hall at Donington Grand Prix Collection]] [[File:McLaren MP4 11.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[David Coulthard]]'s [[McLaren MP4/11|MP4/11]] in the McLaren Hall at Donington Grand Prix Collection.]] The Donington Collection is home to the largest exhibition (being almost comprehensive of the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s) of McLaren vehicles. Highlights of the collection include the #1 [[McLaren M23]] driven by Formula 1 World Champion [[James Hunt]] in 1977, the [[McLaren MP4/14]] chassis number 4, untouched after crossing the line and affirming [[Mika Häkkinen]] as {{F1|1999}} Formula 1 World Champion, also, the 1993 [[McLaren MP4/8|MP4/8]] driven to victory by [[Ayrton Senna]] on location at the [[1993 European Grand Prix]]. An [[McLaren MP4/4|MP4/4]], designed by [[Gordon Murray]] carrying chassis number 3 and being the only example of said model to not win a Grand Prix stands in exhibition of the all conquering McLaren of the [[1988 Formula One season]]. Conversely, its lacklustre predecessor, the [[Steve Nichols]] designed [[McLaren MP4/3|MP4/3]] [[Techniques d'Avant Garde|TAG]] [[Porsche]] twin-turbo stands alongside it in a diachronic exhibition of Mclaren creations. In addition, rarities such as a Häkkinen's [[McLaren MP4/13|MP4/13]] in test livery (prior to the unveiling of their new sponsorship ahead of the [[1998 Formula One season|1998 season]]), an [[McLaren M14A|M14A]] driven by [[Denny Hulme]] and an [[McLaren MP4/2|MP4/2]], the car that took [[Alain Prost]] to his first World Drivers' Championship in [[1985 Formula One season|1985]]. Alongside these lie helmets of great drivers who drove for the Woking based outfit over the years such as Senna, Prost, [[Niki Lauda|Lauda]], Häkkinen, [[Gerhard Berger|Berger]] and [[David Coulthard|Coulthard]]. [[File:McLaren MP4 13 Test Livery.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Mika Häkkinen]]'s [[McLaren MP4/13|MP4/13]] in test livery in the McLaren Hall at Donington Grand Prix Collection.]] {{-}}

{{about|the ATP Tour tournament beginning in 2013|the defunct WTA Tour tournament|Düsseldorf Open (WTA Tour)}} {{Infobox tennis tournament | name = Düsseldorf Open | current = | logo = | logo size = | city = [[Düsseldorf]] | country = {{GER}} | venue = [[Rochusclub]] | founded = 2013 | abolished = 2014 | category = [[ATP World Tour 250 series]] | surface = [[Clay court|Clay]] / [[Tennis court|Outdoors]] | draw = 28S / 32Q / 16D | prize money = €467,800 | website = | notes = }} The '''Düsseldorf Open''' (formerly known as the '''Power Horse Cup''') was a professional men's [[tennis]] tournament played on outdoor [[Clay court|Clay]] in [[Düsseldorf]], [[North Rhine-Westphalia]], [[Germany]]. The event was affiliated with the [[ATP World Tour 250 series|ATP 250]] series, on the [[ATP Tour]]. The initial event took place on 18–25 May 2013.[http://power-horse-cup.com/www/start/ Tournament homepage]{{cite web|title=Düsseldorf to host ATP World Tour 250 tournament|url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2012/10/Features/Dusseldorf-To-Host-ATP-World-Tour-250.aspx|publisher=ATP|date=11 November 2012}}{{cite web|title=Monaco hits from to win inaugural Dusseldorf title|url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2013/05/21/Dusseldorf-Saturday-Monaco-Nieminen.aspx|publisher=ATP|date=25 May 2013}} The 2014 edition of the tournament took place without a title sponsor.{{cite news|author1=Rainer Wallasch|title=Düsseldorf Open: Kohlschreiber triumphiert|url=http://www.wz-newsline.de/lokales/duesseldorf/sport/duesseldorf-open-kohlschreiber-triumphiert-1.1646171|work=Westdeutsche Zeitung|date=25 May 2014}} In 2015, the event was cancelled before the [[2015 ATP World Tour]], due a lack of sponsorship, and the tournament's spot in the schedule was awarded to the [[Geneva Open]].{{cite web|title=ATP Dusseldorf Open dropped due to lack of sponsorship|url=http://www1.skysports.com/tennis/news/12040/9542622/atp-dusseldorf-open-dropped-due-to-lack-of-sponsorship|work=SkySports|date=12 November 2014}} From 2006 until 2008, the Düsseldorf Open were an [[ATP Challenger Tour]] tournament played at the TG Nord tennis courts. == Results == === Singles === {|class="wikitable" |- !Year !width="200"|Champion !width="200"|Runner-up revision.comment: Correction
revision.text:
The '''Elcho Shield''' is an annual [[Match Rifle]] competition between national teams of eight from [[England]], [[Scotland]], [[Ireland]], and [[Wales]]. The trophy holder is able to choose the venue of the competition, however, since the NRA's move to Surrey from Wimbledon in the 19th century, the competition has been held at Bisley Ranges, [[Surrey]], England. Each shooter fires fifteen shots at {{convert|1000|yd|abbr=on}}, {{convert|1100|yd|abbr=on}}, and {{convert|1200|yd|abbr=on}} with, unusually for a shooting discipline, no "sighting" or practice shots. The shooters may be coached which allows other team members to judge and make necessary adjustments to the shooter's sights. The rules allow each team two hours at each range to fire all their shots. The match is most regularly held following the national championships in July each year.
The first match, on Wednesday July 9th 1862, was held over {{convert|800|yd|abbr=on}}, {{convert|900|yd|abbr=on}} and {{convert|1000|yd|abbr=on}} solely between Scotland and England. In the event England won by 166 marks. Scotland won the trophy for the first time in 1864 and Ireland joined the fray in 1865.
The trophy is large and distinctive, known as the Elcho Shield, and is made from a sheet of [[iron]] decorated with repousse scenes to a design by the artist [[George Frederic Watts|G. F. Watts]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Watts|first=M.S.|year=1912|title=George Frederic Watts|location=London|publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Macmillan]]|volume=1|pages=197-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LneiSQAACAAJ}}</ref> It was presented to the [[National Rifle Association of the United Kingdom]] by its founder and president, [[Francis Richard Charteris, 10th Earl of Wemyss|Lord Elcho]] (Francis Richard Charteris, 10th [[Earl of Wemyss]] and 6th [[Earl of March]], b. 1818, d. 1914).
The current holder of the trophy is England (2017).
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.nra.org.uk/ National Rifle Association of the UK]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = National Stadium Sports Complex{{cite web|title=Visiting the Portuguese National Stadium|url=http://www.football-weekends.com/2016/01/19/national-stadium-portugal-ground-visit-16-01-2016/|website=Football-Weekends|publisher=Lucas Laermans|accessdate=19 January 2016|language=English}} | fullname = Complexo Desportivo do Estádio Nacional/Complexo Desportivo do Jamor | image = StadionJamor.JPG|image_size=300px | caption = A view of the National Stadium | location = [[Algés, Linda-a-Velha e Cruz Quebrada-Dafundo]], [[Oeiras Municipality, Portugal|Oeiras]] | coordinates = {{coord|38.708768|-9.260859|type:landmark|display=title}} | broke_ground = 1939 | opened = 10 June 1944{{cite web|title=Estádio de Honra|url=http://jamor.idesporto.pt/index.php?s=white&pid=7|website=Centro Desportivo Nacional do Jamor|publisher=Instituto Português do Desporto e Juventude|accessdate=21 June 2015|language=Portuguese}} | renovated = September 2012 | capacity = 37,593 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Portuguese Football Federation]] | operator = | surface = [[Grass]] | construction_cost = | architect = Miguel Jacobetty Rosa | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Portugal national football team]]
[[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] (2003)
[[C.F. Os Belenenses|Belenenses]] [[Sociedade Anónima Desportiva|SAD]] (2018–) | dimensions = {{convert|105|x|68|m|ft}} }} The '''National Stadium Sports Complex''' ({{lang-pt|Complexo Desportivo do Estádio Nacional/Complexo Desportivo do Jamor}}), also known as ''Jamor Sports Complex'', is a [[List of national stadiums|national football ground]] used by the [[Portugal national football team|Portugal national team]] and, as of 2018, by [[C.F. Os Belenenses|Belenenses]] [[Sociedade Anónima Desportiva|SAD]]. It is located in the [[Freguesia (Portugal)|civil parish]] of [[Algés, Linda-a-Velha e Cruz Quebrada-Dafundo]], in the [[Concelho|municipality]] of [[Oeiras, Portugal|Oeiras]], in the western part of [[Lisbon District]]. The stadium entered UEFA history as host of the first ever game played in UEFA club competitions. The game was played on 4 September 1955 between [[1954–55 Primeira Divisão|Primeira Divisão]]'s third-placed team, [[Sporting CP]], and Yugoslav champions, Serbian side [[FK Partizan|Partizan Belgrade]]. It ended as a 3–3 draw and was the first game to be played of the [[1955–56 European Cup|first edition]] of the [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]].{{Cite web|url = http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=2274124.html|title = When Sporting and Partizan broke new ground|date = 4 September 2015|accessdate = 22 December 2015|website = www.uefa.com|publisher = José Nuno Pimentel|last = |first = }} ==History== In 1933, the decision was made to construct the national stadium alongside the Jamor ravine.{{citation |url=http://www.monumentos.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=22419 |title=Complexo Desportivo do Estádio Nacional/Complexo Desportivo do Jamor (IPA.00022419/PT031110080066) |publisher=SIPA – Sistema de Informação para o Património Arquitectónico |location=Lisbon, Portugal |language=Portuguese |first=Patrícia |last=Costa |first2=Margarida |last2=Elias |editor=Centro de Investigação em Arquitectura, Urbanismo e Design (CIAUD-FA/UTL) |year=2014 |accessdate=5 May 2017}} The original design was authored by [[Francisco Caldeira Cabral]] and Konrad Weisner Do Estádio Nacional ao Jardim Gulbenkian, Francisco Caldeira Cabral e a Primeira Geração de Arquitectos Paisagistas, de Teresa Andresen{{cite web|url=http://proffranciscocaldeiracabral.portaldojardim.com/projectos/o-estadio-nacional-e-a-polemica-que-envolveu-este-projecto/|title=Centenário Francisco Caldeira Cabral » O Estádio Nacional e a polémica que envolveu este projecto.|author=|date=|website=proffranciscocaldeiracabral.portaldojardim.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} and [[Jacobetty Rosa]], with working beginning in 1939. It was inaugurated on 10 June 1944 ([[Portugal Day]]) by the [[Prime-minister|Council president]] [[António Oliveira Salazar]]. Work was complete in the Quinta da Graça (in 1953), to install the ''Comissão Administrativa do Estádio Nacional'' (''National Stadium Administrative Commission''). In 1961, construction on the hippodrome began, in addition to the first phase of work on the shooting range, by the ''Serviços de Construção e de Conservação'' (''Construction and Conservation Services''). The ''Plano de Ordenamento do Complexo Desportivo da Jamor'' (''Jamor Sports Complex Development Plan'') was issued on July 1982, ordered by the DGEMN ''Direção-Geral de Edifícios e Monumentos Nacionais'' (''Directorate-General for Buildings and National Monuments''), authored by the architects Vasco Croft (coordinator), Nuno Bártolo and Joaquim Cadima, and by the landscape firm Professor Caldeira Cabral, Associados, Estudos e Projectos, Ld. (under the direction of landscape architects Francisco Caldeira Cabral and agronomist engineer João Caldeira Cabral. During this phase, diagnostic studies were performed to reformulate and re-evaluate the strategic importance of the complex. In May 1985, the study ''Estabelecimento de zona de protecção'' (to establish a protection zone) was ordered by the DGEMN, by architects Vasco Croft and Nuno Bártolo, to limit the sports complex zone, providing a buffer for military access, a ''non aedificandi'' zone and urban growth, in addition to spansion for greenspaces and support areas for nautical sports. In 1993, a project to construct a sporting pavilion in Jamor was issued. In September 2012, the [[Portuguese Football Federation]] announced that the stadium would undergo renovation in which work would begin in 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.abola.pt/nnh/ver.aspx?id=350939 |title=Jamor vai acolher a "Cidade do Futebol": obras começam em 2014 |trans-title=Jamor will host the "Soccer City": works begin in 2014 |work=[[A Bola]] |language=Portuguese |date=5 September 2012 |accessdate=26 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030224643/http://www.abola.pt/nnh/ver.aspx?id=350939 |archivedate=30 October 2012 |df= }} It was announced by the Rugby governing body [[European Rugby Cup|ERC]] on 2 September that the Portuguese team would hold their home games at the Estádio Nacional.http://www.ercrugby.com/eng/news/22029.php#.UiS1Kza-2So {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130905092645/http://www.ercrugby.com/eng/news/22029.php |date=2013-09-05 }} However, all their home games were played at the [[Portugal national rugby union team|Portuguese national rugby teams]] home stadium of [[Estádio Universitário de Lisboa]]. On 6 February 2015, a tender was issued to cover the western edge of the audience seating for the rugby field. ==Architecture== Architecturally the stadium is noteworthy for its open east side, unusual for a stadium otherwise featuring a typical oval configuration. Its current capacity is 39,000 and it is the venue for the Portuguese football cup final. ==Sport== ===Football=== The stadium has traditionally hosted the final of the [[Cup of Portugal|Portuguese Cup]] (since 1946); in only five times was this game played in other venues and in total, 52 Cup finals have been played on the grounds. Portuguese football fans have bemoaned the historic stadium, owing to a lack of amenities; following the Euro 2004, there was a movement to move the event to one of the grounds built for the Euro football championships. The most prestigious international game ever staged at the ''Estádio Nacional'' was the [[European Cup 1966-67|1967 European Cup]] [[1967 European Cup Final|final]], played between [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] and [[F.C. Internazionale Milano|Internazionale]] with the former winning 2-1 (becoming the first [[United Kingdom|British]] European champion team, nicknamed the ''[[Lisbon Lions]]''). In addition to hosting the [[Portugal national football team|Portuguese national team]] since in 1945, the site has held 49 international events for Portugal. {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="font-size:85%" ! #FFFFCC" | 49. || 31 May 2014 || 0–0 || {{fb|Greece}} || Friendly |} ===Rugby=== The Rugby governing body [[European Rugby Cup|ERC]] announced on 2 September 2014 that the Portuguese club [[Lusitanos XV]] would hold their home games of the [[2013–14 European Challenge Cup|2013-14 Amlin Challenge Cup]] at National Stadium.[http://www.ercrugby.com/eng/news/22029.php#.UiS1Kza-2So ERCRugby.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130905092645/http://www.ercrugby.com/eng/news/22029.php |date=2013-09-05 }} However, all their home games of the 2013-14 Amlin Challenge Cup were played at the [[Portugal national rugby union team|Portuguese national rugby teams]] home stadium of [[Estádio Universitário de Lisboa]]. ==Events== There have been notable concert events from the site, including [[The Police]] (who performed on 25 September 2007), as part of their [[The Police Reunion Tour]], and the [[Black Eyed Peas]], on 30 May 2010, during their [[The E.N.D. World Tour]]. ==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Sources=== {{citation |title=Relatório da Actividade do Ministério no Ano de 1961 |location=Lisbon, Portugal |publisher=Ministério das Obras Públicas |year=1962 |volume=1 |language=Portuguese}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]]
[[European Cup and Champions League finals|Final Venue]]| before=[[King Baudouin Stadium|Heysel Stadium]]
[[Brussels]]| after=[[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]]
[[London]]| years=[[1966–67 European Cup|1967]] }} {{s-end}} {{Portugal national football team}} {{Portugal national football team results}} {{UEFA Champions League Final venues}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nacional}} [[Category:Football venues in Portugal]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in Portugal]] [[Category:National stadiums]] [[Category:Portuguese New State architecture|Estadio Nacional]] [[Category:Sports venues in Lisbon District]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Oeiras|Estadio Nacional]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1944]] [[Category:Sport in Oeiras]]

{{Infobox sport overview | boxwidth = 250 | title = Football in Iraq | image = | imagesize = 240px | image_alt = | caption = | union = [[Iraq Football Association]] | country = Iraq | sport = football | noncountry = | teamlabel1 = | nationalteam = [[Iraq national football team|men's national team]] | teamlabel2 = | repteam = | nickname = | first = | registered = | clubs = | national_list = | club_list = [[Iraqi Premier League]] | intl_list = [[AFC Cup]]
[[Arab Club Champions Cup]]
[[FIFA World Cup]]
[[AFC Asian Cup|Asian Cup]] | match = | league = }} The [[sport]] of '''[[football (soccer)|football]]''' in the country of '''[[Iraq]]''' is run by the [[Iraq Football Association]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wsc.co.uk/the-archive/917-International-football/2488-war-games |title=When Saturday Comes - War games |publisher=Wsc.co.uk |date=2012-07-09 |accessdate=2012-09-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sabotagetimes.com/football-sport/the-state-of-football-in-post-saddam-iraq/ |title=State Of Football In Iraq | Football & Sport |publisher=Sabotage Times |date= |accessdate=2012-09-19}} The association administers the [[Iraq national football team|national football team]] as well as the [[Iraqi Premier League]].{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/nathan-harden/soccer-could-save-iraq_b_662003.html |title=Nathan Harden: Soccer Could Save Iraq |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= 2010-07-28|accessdate=2012-09-19}}{{cite web|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/nationworld/2003812430_soccer30.html |title=Nation & World | Soccer title brings rare gift: Iraq unity | Seattle Times Newspaper |publisher=Seattletimes.com |date=2007-07-30 |accessdate=2012-09-19}}{{cite news|last=Karon |first=Tony |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1647039,00.html |title=Iraqi Soccer Reaches a Goooooooal! |publisher=TIME |date=2007-07-25 |accessdate=2012-09-19}}{{cite news|author=BBC's Sally Nugent |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9008015.stm |title=BBC Sport - Football - Iraqi team helping people unite |publisher=BBC News |date=2010-09-17 |accessdate=2012-09-19}}{{cite news|last=Arun |first=Neil |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/8146125.stm |title=Middle East | When football came home to Iraq |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-07-11 |accessdate=2012-09-19}}{{cite news|title= Soccer in Iraq: Another Field for Argument |publisher= The New York Times|date=2009-11-24|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/25/world/middleeast/25baghdad.html|accessdate=2012-09-19|first1=Rod|last1=Nordland|first2=Sa'ad|last2=Al-Izzi}}{{cite news|last=Lucinda |first=Hannah |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-28160003 |title=Should Iraq's leaders be more like their football players? - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-07-01}} Football is the most popular sport in Iraq.http://i.imgur.com/2Q6slko.png ==National teams== The national team have qualified for the final tournament of the [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] once in [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986]] which was held in [[Mexico]]. Success in the [[AFC Asian Cup|Asian Cup]] has been more widespread, winning the tournament in [[2007 AFC Asian Cup|2007]] and finishing fourth in [[1976 AFC Asian Cup|1976]] and [[2015 AFC Asian Cup|2015]]. As of 2015 the [[Iraq women's national football team|women's national team]] have not entered either of these competitions. The [[Iraq national under-23 football team|under-23 side]] has had success at the [[Asian Games]] winning silver at the [[Football at the 2006 Asian Games|2006 edition]] in [[Qatar]] and bronze in [[Football at the 2014 Asian Games|2014]], [[South Korea]]. Their best placing in [[Olympic football]] has been fourth at [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Athens]] in 2004. As for 29 June 2015 the men's team were [[FIFA World Rankings|ranked]] 86th in the world{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/fifa-world-ranking/ranking-table/men/index.html |title=FIFA rankings |publisher=fifa.com |date=2015-06-29 |accessdate=2015-06-29}} and the women's team joint 138th (and last) due to being inactive.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/fifa-world-ranking/ranking-table/women/index.html |title=FIFA rankings |publisher=fifa.com |date=2015-06-29 |accessdate=2015-06-29}} ==Club tournaments== [[Al-Shorta SC]] reached the final of the [[1971 Asian Champion Club Tournament|1971 AFC Champions League]], the biggest tournament in Asian football, but withdrew from the final due to it being against an Israeli team; Israel were subsequently expelled from the AFC and the Arab media considers Al-Shorta to be the tournament's winners that year. [[Al-Rasheed SC]] also reached the final in [[1988–89 Asian Club Championship|1989]] but lost on away goals. Those same two clubs are the only Iraqi teams to have won the [[Arab Club Champions Cup]]; Al-Shorta won the first ever edition in [[1980–82 Arab Club Champions Cup|1982]] with Al-Rasheed winning that competition three times in a row (1985, 1986, 1987). In terms of second-tier continental cups, [[Al-Quwa Al-Jawiya]] won the [[AFC Cup]] in both [[2016 AFC Cup|2016]] and [[2017 AFC Cup|2017]]. ==Domestic league titles won by club== {{Main article|List of Iraqi football champions#Total titles won}} ==See also== *[[Women's football in Iraq]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.iraqi-football.com Iraqi Football Website] {{Football in Iraq}} {{Asia in topic|Football in}} [[Category:Football in Iraq| ]] [[Category:Football in the Arab states of the Persian Gulf]] {{Iraq-sport-stub}} {{footy-stub}}

revision.text:
{{ infobox stadium | name = Hazza bin Zayed Stadium | nickname = Al Ain Stadium{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} | logo_image = [[File:Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium logo.png|150px]] | image = Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium-1600x508.jpg | image_size = 300px | fullname = Hazza bin Zayed Stadium | location = [[Al Ain]], [[United Arab Emirates]] | coordinates = {{coord|24.245594|55.716583|name=Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1 June 2012 | built = 2012–2014 (2 years) | opened = 14 January 2014 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Al Ain FC]] | operator = [[Al Ain FC]] | surface = Grass | cost = 145 million [[United Arab Emirates Dirham|Dirham]] ([[US Dollar|US$]]39.4 million) | construction_cost = | architect = Pattern Design Limited{{fact|date=July 2018}} | structural engineer = EC Harris{{fact|date=July 2018}} | services engineer = | general_contractor = BAM International{{fact|date=July 2018}} | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Al Ain FC]] (2014–present) | website = {{URL|http://hbzstadium.ae}} | capacity = 25,965 | dimensions = | scoreboard = Yes }} The '''Hazza bin Zayed Stadium''' ({{lang-ar|استاد هزاع بن زايد}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]], located in the Emirate of [[Abu Dhabi]], City of [[Al Ain]], [[United Arab Emirates]]. It is the home stadium of [[Al Ain FC]] of the [[UAE Pro-League]]. The stadium holds 22,717 spectators and opened in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uae.agleague.ae/en/club/al-ain.html|title=Al Ain - Clubs - UAE Pro League Committee|first=XS|last=Studios|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="Al Ain's Hazza bin Zayed Stadium nears completion">{{cite news |title=Al Ain's Hazza bin Zayed Stadium nears completion|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/uae-news/in-pictures-al-ain-s-hazza-bin-zayed-stadium-nears-completion|newspaper=The National|date=|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> The stadium was named after the chairman of the club, Sheikh [[Hazza bin Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan]].
The 45,000sqm Hazza bin Zayed stadium is split over seven levels, and is one of the most modern sporting venues in the [[Middle East]]. It is one of the most sophisticated sports venues in the region.
The stadium was broke ground in April 2012 and was completed in December 2014. It was planned that [[Al Ain FC|Al Ain]] faced [[Manchester City]] in the inaugural ceremony of the stadium,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenational.ae/uae/manchester-city-to-play-al-ain-at-opening-of-hazza-bin-zayed-stadium|title=Manchester City to play Al Ain at opening of Hazza bin Zayed Stadium|newspaper=The National (United Arab Emirates)|date=1 January 2014}}</ref> but City drew 1–1 with [[Blackburn Rovers]] in an [[2013–14 FA Cup#Third round proper|English FA Cup]] match on 4 January and a replay with Rovers scheduled on 15 January prevented the English [[Premier League]] champions from a trip to the UAE.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenational.ae/sport/football/manchester-city-will-not-play-in-al-ain|newspaper=The National (United Arab Emirates)|title=Manchester City will not play in Al Ain|date=8 January 2014}}</ref> However the friendly was instead played after the Premier League season was over and Manchester City beat Al Ain 3–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2629147/Al-Ain-vs-Manchester-City-live-Follow-post-season-friendly-UAE-happens.html|title=Al Ain 0-3 Manchester City: Samir Nasri on form|publisher=}}</ref> The stadium will also host the [[2017 FIFA Club World Cup|2017]] and [[2018 FIFA Club World Cup|2018]] [[FIFA Club World Cup]]s and the [[2019 AFC Asian Cup]].
==Location and design== [[File:Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium night.jpg|thumb|left|Night illumination of the stadium [[façade]] during stadium's opening]] The 25,000 seat stadium is located in [[Al Ain]], approximately 150 kilometres east of [[Abu Dhabi]], close to the borders of [[Oman]]. It was designed and built under a contract for a multi-functional stadium in the [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baminternational.com/projects/hazza-bin-zayed-stadium-abu-dhabi|title=Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium - Abu Dhabi - BAM International|publisher=}}</ref>
Client was represented by AAFAQ Holdings. The project was realised in close cooperation with sister companies [[Royal BAM Group|BAM Sports]], specialised in stadium construction, and BAM Contractors from [[Ireland]]. The scope of work included the construction of a multi-functional stadium with a gross floor area of 45,000 square metres. In addition BAM built a six-storey office building, a sports hall and external works comprising roads, car parking, playing fields and landscaping. The stadium architects were London based Pattern Design.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pattern-architects.com/project/hazza-bin-zayed-stadium|title=Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium - Pattern|publisher=}}</ref>
One of the most characteristic elements of the stadium is the external facade which consists of fabric elements resembling the trunk of a palm tree that also can be lighted by [[LED]] lights in 15 different content modes. On the top of the stadium roof, 200 floodlights are fixed to provide the illumination of after-dark soccer games. Due to the extreme temperatures during the hot summer months, the palm bowl shape of the roof also provides pleasant conditions for both the players and the fans. It is one of the stadium's unique features, which is designed in a way that matches can take place in the shadow after 5pm. On the inside, it reveals the complex geometry of its cantilevered steel trusses, which was achieved by using robotic cutting and welding technology. The stadium is the first stadium in the world to featuring a unique parasol roof designed specifically to fully shade all fans.<ref>[http://www.baminternational.com/sites/default/files/domain-61/documents/002456_-_235_hazza_bin_zayed_stadium_and_mixed_use_development_al_ain_abu_dhabi_uae-61-13935765141872114764.pdf Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium and mixed use development, Al Ain, UAE]</ref>
Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium was voted Stadium of the Year 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stadiumdb.com/competitions/stadium_of_the_year_2014#jury|title=Stadium of the Year 2014 – StadiumDB.com|publisher=}}</ref>
==History== The stadium has been completed after a 16-month ultra-fast track construction project after being started on 1 June 2012. Built to [[FIFA]] standards, the stadium covers an area of 45,000 square metres with a capacity of 25,000 seats. The scope of the project further included a sports hall, commercial buildings and extensive exterior landscaping. The stadium is part of another further development that covers 500,000 square metres and includes 700 apartments, green spaces, two office buildings, 50 restaurants, shops and a 170-room hotel.
The project is the first component of this broader development that will have its effect first on the city of [[Al Ain]], but also on the wider region including the neighboring countries of the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]]. It was a design and build contract. BAM introduced a lot of value engineering proposals which had to be integrated into the design and therefore new building permits were required within the 18 months. BAM International started the project in mid-2012 and remained right on schedule with all aspects of the construction, making use of 10.5 million man hours. At peak there were 400 men staff up to the supervisor level and 4500 labourers on site.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.archdaily.com/604755/hazza-bin-zayed-stadium-pattern-design/|title=Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium / Pattern Design|date=4 March 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
==Facilities== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium inside.jpg|thumb|250px|Interior of the stadium]] --> The stadium is an integral part of a new, wider community. Over the next four years, it will become the centrepiece of a planned 500,000 square-metre development that will include a 175-room [[hotel]], a community of 700 residential units in a complex of apartments and green spaces, two office buildings, a sports centre, retail outlets and 50 restaurants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/sport/football/hazza-bin-zayed-stadium-a-setting-fit-for-premier-league-kings|title=Hazza bin Zayed Stadium a setting fit for Premier League kings - The National|publisher=}}</ref>
==Transportation== There are a number of routes to get to Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hbzstadium.ae/location/|title=Location - HAZZA BIN ZAYED STADIUM|date=6 December 2013|publisher=}}</ref> The stadium is 15 minutes from [[Al Ain Airport]].
Route A: From [[Abu Dhabi]]: *On leaving the suburbs of [[Al Ain]], pass through [[Al Yahar]] area, and take the exit that leads to Al Salamat area. *Cross straight through Al Salamat roundabout, and continue through the area of Al Bateen to EXTRA Mall. *Cross straight across over a number of roundabouts until you reach Al Tawia Garden roundabout. *Cross straight over Al Tawia Garden roundabout and the Stadium will be on your left.
Route B: From Abu Dhabi: *Pass through Al Maqam area and cross the Tawam Roundabout to (Al Daiwan Roundabout No 178). *Straight across the roundabout and the entrance to the stadium in on the right.
Route C: From [[Dubai]]: *Drive to [[Al Ain]] city through Dubai – Al Ain road. *Pass through Al Hayer area and continue on the high way until you reach Al Ain Dairy Farms which will be on the right. *Turn left at the next exit and continue straight on and follow the signs to [[UAE University]] and Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium. *At the roundabout take left and cross straight on and the entrance to the stadium will be on the right.
Route D: From [[Fujairah]]: *Take [[Sheikh Mohamed Bin Zayed]] road ([[Emirates Road]]) and join the Dubai –Al Ain Road. *Pass through Al Hayer area and continue on the high way until you reach Al Ain Dairy Farms which will be on the right. *Turn left at the next exit and continues straight on and follows the signs to UAE University and Hazza Bin Zayed Stadium.
{{wide image|بانوراما-ملعب-هزاع-بن-زايد-بالداخل.jpg|800px|align-cap=center|A Panorama view of the stadium interior|100%}}
==2019 AFC Asian Cup== Hazza bin Zayed Stadium will host eight games of the 2019 AFC Asian Cup, including a Round of 16, quarter-final and semi-final match. {{anchor|AC2019}} {{clear}} {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:100%;" |- !Date !Time !Team No. 1 !Res. !Team No. 2 !Round !Attendance |- |6 January 2019||15:00|| {{fb|AUS}} ||style="text-align:center;"| Match 2 || {{fb|JOR}} ||[[2019 AFC Asian Cup Group B|Group B]]||style="text-align:center;"| |- |9 January 2019||20:00|| {{fb|QAT}} ||style="text-align:center;"| Match 12 || {{fb|LBN}} ||[[2019 AFC Asian Cup Group E|Group E]]||style="text-align:center;"| |- |11 January 2019||20:00|| {{fb|KGZ}} ||style="text-align:center;"| Match 18 || {{fb|KOR}} ||[[2019 AFC Asian Cup Group C|Group C]]||style="text-align:center;"| |--- |13 January 2019||20:00|| {{fb|UAE}} ||style="text-align:center;"| Match 25 || {{fb|THA}} ||[[2019 AFC Asian Cup Group A|Group A]]||style="text-align:center;"| |- |16 January 2019||20:00|| {{fb|VIE}} ||style="text-align:center;"| Match 31 || {{fb|YEM}} ||[[2019 AFC Asian Cup Group D|Group D]]||style="text-align:center;"| |- |20 January 2019||18:00|| Runner-up Group A ||style="text-align:center;"| Match 38 || Runner-up Group C ||[[2019 AFC Asian Cup knockout stage|Round of 16]]||style="text-align:center;"| |- |25 January 2019||20:00|| Winner Match 42 ||style="text-align:center;"| Match 48 || Winner Match 41 ||[[2019 AFC Asian Cup knockout stage|Quarter-finals]]||style="text-align:center;"| |- |28 January 2019||18:00|| Winner Match 46 ||style="text-align:center;"| Match 49 || Winner Match 45 ||[[2019 AFC Asian Cup knockout stage|Semi-finals]]||style="text-align:center;"| |}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commonscat|Hazza bin Zayed Stadium}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140622153410/http://www.hbzstadium.ae/hazza_bin_zayed_stadium/index.html HBZ Stadium official website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090516045338/http://www.alainfc.net/ Al Ain Sports & Cultural Club Official website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140529115035/http://www.hbzstadium.ae/en/ HBZStadium Official website]
